title.narrative: Leaders of Peace - Plan International African Union Liaison Office (AULO) Project

description.narrative: 2020 marks the 20th anniversary of the adoption of UN Security Council Resolution 1325 on women, peace and security. Therefore, it is time to re-emphasize the important role of (young) women in peacebuilding in South Sudan. The voices of young people, girls and boys, need to be heard in these dialogues and reconciliation processes – especially those at the heart of conflict. It remains crucial that the positive contribution of women and youth to sustainable peace and state building is recognized, supported and celebrated. In this prospect, the Plan African Union will contribute to the programme's Result Area 3 (Increased and effective participation of W/Y in leadership and peacebuilding).

Beneficiaries are community members in South Sudan. More specifically, girls and women as well as the community as a whole through a more enabling environment for girls and women that creates a stronger society.
Ownership by the local community will be important as well; for that the local context and prevelent social norms have to be taken into consideration.

Result Area 3: Increased and effective participation of W/Y in leadership and peacebuilding. Increased, influential participation of W/Y in leadership and peacebuilding is possible when W/Y facilitate political positioning and influencing across ethnic/religious/conflict lines, together with male counterparts.

SUMMARY: South Sudan has been engaged in a peace process for years. It remains important to emphasize the role of women and youth in peacebuilding and reconciliation processes. As part of the National Action Plan of the Dutch government to support the implementation of the UN resolution 1325, the consortium consisting of Plan International, AMA, EVE, HealthNet and PAX is implementing the Leaders of Peace Programme. It aims at a more empowering and inclusive environment in South Sudan. Women and girls will feel safer and better enabled to assert their rights, so they can play an influential role towards conflict prevention and sustainable peace. The project will be carried out by the Plan International African Union Liaison Office from January 2021 to December 2025. It will be implemented in South Sudan (East, West & Central Equatoria, Unity, Lakes) and the learnings from the project will be used for advocacy at the continental/AU level.

The Leaders of Peace Programme builds up on successes of the Women and Girls for Change Programme (WGFC 2016-2020), building on activities related to psychosocial support, peacebuilding and prevention of GBV activities implemented by other actors with a focus on Lobby and Advocacy.
